title: House of Splendid Isolation
text:
House of Splendid Isolation is a <a href="1994%20in%20literature">1994 novel</a> by Irish novelist <a href="Edna%20O%27Brien">Edna O'Brien</a>. The novel depicts the relations of an <a href="Irish%20Republican%20Army">Irish Republican Army</a> terrorist and his hostage, an elderly woman. The novel brings elements of the <a href="Thriller%20%28genre%29">thriller</a> genre to O'Brien's ongoing explorations of Irish society. It is based on the life of <a href="Dominic%20McGlinchy">Dominic McGlinchy</a>, whom O'Brien interviewed while incarcerated in <a href="Portlaoise%20Prison">Portlaoise Prison</a>.
Reception.
"<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>" gave a mediocre review calling the novel both "a brave book, and if it does not altogether succeed, [and an] attempt nonetheless [that] merits praise." The review notes that the novel is a "dramatic departure" from O'Brien's typical novels, and in that context of experiment "we see her audacity fail and her elegant prose run badly out of control." "<a href="The%20Independent">The Independent</a>" was decidedly negative, writing "there could hardly be a neater illustration of O'Brien's fatal humourlessness, and of the extent to which too much posing as a tragedy queen has turned her deaf to her own bathetic effects."
"<a href="Publishers%20Weekly">Publishers Weekly</a>" was slightly more positive, noting that the scenes about McGreevy the terrorist were unsuccessful, but describing the novel on a whole as "Powerful, however, is the elegiac voice on themes of womanly love, the tale's psychological acuity and the re-creation of a haunted landscape." "<a href="Kirkus%20Reviews">Kirkus Reviews</a>" describes it as successful, its "well worth reading as O'Brien's first concentrated treatment of the troubles--and the pain they visit on the Irish people."
